title: How to improve my GRE scores in the verbal and writing sections - Quora

response.answer_text: The verbal and writing sections are in a way interlinked, as one can help to improve the other. However, when trying to improve your scores there are some key things to keep in mind. Firstly, I would suggest looking very closely at the mistakes. I cannot stress this enough - It is important to understand exactly where you are going wrong and then use that to create a direction and game plan for improvement. Once this has been identified, there are a lot of resources out there that can help you systematically approach the problem and improve on them. Perhaps, you are only good at slow reading and need improvement in your speed, or maybe you need to build your vocabulary more. Your unique problems needs to be identified - FYI, I’ve listed below some resources that helped me tackle some specific problems. Although there is NO substitute to continuous reading and building a strong foundation, there are some tips and tricks that past test takers can help you get some insight into the test. Take for example Reading Comprehension or Vocabulary Building Apps. There are some great resources on general tips as well such as : GRE General Tips

I recently published a blog post on how to better prepare for GRE. The main takeaways from the post are: If you have a significant amount of time on your hand, you should definitely get yourself a ‘Word Power Made Easy’ and start with it as soon as you can. This will help you prepare the base for learning new wordsLearn a LOT of words: There is no shortcut to this and you need to be familiar with a whole lot words before you take your test. The questions in the GRE often present similar looking/sounding words as the options to most of the questions and you would not have any idea if you haven’t faced some of them beforePractice practice and practice again: All the efforts towards your preparation can go to waste if you don’t devote a significant amount of your time towards practice tests. The two official tests for ETS (which also happen to be free) are a must!Read the full post The GRE Monster to get links to helpful study materials and other tips to help you prepare better for the GRE.
